Description: Fragment of left side of East Greek terracotta figure vase (plastic vase) in the form of a horse's head. Horse is represented with its head drawn close to its neck. Spout lost. Mould-made with 'black glaze' painted details for mane, eye and bridle. Orange-brown fine Milesian (?) clay fabric with common very fine mica inclusions.
Curator's comments: Two similar parallels dated slightly earlier, to early 6th century BC (BM1860,0404.27; BM1860,0201.43) were excavated at Kamiros. Higgins cites a late 6th century BC parallel also from Kamiros (Higgins 1959, 25). Originally thought to be made in Rhodes (Higgins 1959, 35), but probably East Greek as per BM1888,0601.659 that has a similar fabric, which Jones places within his East Greek, probably Milesian group (Jones 1985, 673). NAA analysis suggests this is the same fabric as GR 1888.0601.659. Jones, R. E. 1985. Greek and Cypriot Pottery: A Review of Scientific Studies. Athens.
There are two modern graffiti on the inside, one 'HERA' indicating the find-spot, the other uncertain.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (1638)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.027) (Phase 3)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Committee of)
